clues.answer: Anything that has mass and occupies space.

clues.clue: Is light considered matter? Why or why not?
clues.answer: No; it has no mass and does not occupy space.

clues.clue: Name the three states of matter discussed for our purposes.
clues.answer: Solid, liquid, gas.

clues.clue: Give one example of a physical change and why it’s not chemical.
clues.answer: Ice melting: state changes but composition (H2O) remains the same.

clues.clue: Differentiate physical vs chemical property with one clear example each.
clues.answer: Physical: density of gold; Chemical: silver reacts with nitric acid to form silver nitrate.

clues.clue: How many particles in a mole?
clues.answer: 6.022 × 10^23 (Avogadro’s number).

clues.clue: 1 mol of carbon-12 has what mass?

clues.answer: Mass per mole; g/mol.

clues.clue: How many atoms are in 2.0 mol of O2?
clues.answer: 2.41 × 10^24 atoms (2 mol × 6.022e23 × 2 atoms/molecule).
Moles of solute per liter of solution.
Moles of solute per kilogram of solvent.
15 g KCl per 100 mL solution.

clues.clue: Dilution: 0.010 L of 1.00 M HCl diluted to 1.0 L → new molarity?
How many grams KCl in 1.0 L of a 15% (w/v) solution?
First Law of Thermodynamics in one line.
clues.answer: Energy is neither created nor destroyed; only converted.

clues.clue: Exothermic ΔH sign? Endothermic ΔH sign?
clues.answer: Exothermic: ΔH < 0; Endothermic: ΔH > 0.
Measure of disorder/randomness of a system.
ΔG < 0 → spontaneous; ΔG > 0 → nonspontaneous.

clues.clue: Calculate spontaneity: ΔH = −11.5 kJ, ΔS = +22 J/mol·K at 298 K.
clues.answer: ΔG = ΔH − TΔS ≈ −11.5 kJ − (0.022 kJ/K×298 K) ≈ −18.1 kJ → spontaneous.
Acid donates H+; Base accepts H+.
Completely dissociates into ions in water.

clues.clue: In water at 25 °C, what is Kw?

clues.answer: A solution that resists large pH changes when small amounts of acid or base are added.
P ∝ 1/V at constant T and n (P1V1 = P2V2).
V ∝ T at constant P and n (V1/T1 = V2/T2), T in Kelvin.
P ∝ T at constant V and n (P1/T1 = P2/T2), T in Kelvin.
V ∝ n at constant P and T.
P1V1/T1 = P2V2/T2 (n constant).

finalJeopardy.clue: You’re preparing volatile anesthetic delivery. Name TWO concepts—one from equilibrium/thermo and one from gas laws—that directly determine delivered concentration to the patient.
finalJeopardy.answer: Thermo/Equilibrium: vapor–liquid equilibrium (Keq, ΔG). Gas laws: PV=nRT relations (T and P affecting vapor). Together they set partial pressures in the circuit.
